text: Life is really simple, but we insist on making it complicated.
author: Confucius

text: In this world there are only two tragedies. One is getting what one wants and the other is not getting it.
author: Oscar Wilde

text: The real voyage of discovery consists not in seeking new lands but seeing with new eyes.
author: Marcel Proust

text: Let us be grateful to people who make us happy; they are the charming gardeners who make our souls blossom.
author: Marcel Proust

text: Happiness is beneficial for the body, but it is grief that develops the powers of the mind.
author: Marcel Proust

text: We don't receive wisdom; we must discover it for ourselves after a journey that no one can take for us or spare us.
author: Marcel Proust

text: If a little dreaming is dangerous, the cure for it is not to dream less but to dream more, to dream all the time.
author: Marcel Proust

text: Love is space and time measured by the heart.
author: Marcel Proust

text: Let us leave the beautiful women to men with no imagination.
author: Marcel Proust

text: Illness is the doctor to whom we pay most heed; to kindness, to knowledge, we make promise only; pain we obey.

text: We are healed from suffering only by experiencing it to the full.
author: Marcel Proust

text: It is our imagination that is responsible for love, not the other person.
author: Marcel Proust

text: I'm monogamous in all my relationships
author: Esther Perel

text: Even when laws have been written down, they ought not always to remain unaltered.

text: I would rather have questions that can't be answered than answers which can't be questioned.

text: Everything in the world is about sex except sex. Sex is about power.
author: Oscar Wilde

text: It is possible to fail in many ways...while to succeed is possible only in one way.
author: Aristotle

text: You are never more likely to make a grammatical error than when correcting someone else's grammar.

author: Muphry's Law

text: Moderation is the secret of survival.
author: Manly Hall

text: The world is nothing but change. Our life is only perception.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Getting over yourself offers exceptional returns.
author: Shane Parrish

text: The envious person grows lean with the fatness of their neighbour.
author: Socrates

text: To begin, begin.
author: William Wordsworth

text: Growth begins when we begin to accept our own weakness.

text: Be not ashamed of mistakes and thus make them crimes.

text: There are no secrets except those that keep themselves.

text: The energy of the mind is the essence of life.
author: Aristotle

text: A market is never saturated with a good product, but it is very quickly saturated with a bad one.

text: We are never definitely right, we can only be sure we are wrong.

text: At first, people refuse to believe that a strange new thing can be done, then they begin to hope it can be done, then they see it can be done - then it is done, and all the world wonders why it was not done centuries ago.

text: I am long on ideas, but short on time. I expect to live only about a hundred years.

text: There is no dependence that can be sure but a dependence on one's self.
author: John Gray

text: People would do better, if they knew better.

text: Our plans miscarry because they have no aim. When a man does not know what harbor he is making for, no wind is the right wind.

text: Hope is a poor hedge
author: Unknown

text: It is greed to do all the talking but not to want to listen at all.

text: Memory is the treasury and guardian of all things.

text: I measure the strength of a spirit by how much truth it can take.

text: The rest I keep silent; a great ox stands on my tongue.

text: All that really belongs to us is time; even he who has nothing else has that.

text: Sleep that knits up the raveled sleeve of care, The death of each day’s life, sore labour’s bath, Balm of hurt minds, great nature’s second course, Chief nourisher in life’s feast.

author: Mark Twain

text: If your ship doesn't come swim out to meet it.
author: Jonathan Winters

text: When faced with competing alternative courses of action or competing conclusions, choose the one that rests upon the fewest assumptions.
author: Occam's razor

text: Time discovers truth.
author: Seneca

text: Not everything that counts can be counted, and not everything that can be counted counts.
author: Albert Einstein

text: Your pain is the breaking of the shell that encloses your understanding.
author: Kahil Gibran

text: Most men die at 27. We just bury them at 72.
author: Mark Twain

text: One repays a teacher badly if one always remains nothing but a pupil.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

text: The past is certain, the future obscure.
author: Thales

text: What is a friend? A single soul dwelling in two bodies.
author: Aristotle

text: I can show you where to dig, and what to dig for, but the digging you must do for yourself.
author: Matisyahu

text: It is the chiefest point of happiness that a man is willing to be what he is.
author: Desiderius Erasmus

text: Much learning does not teach understanding.
author: Heraclitus

text: The self is not something ready-made, but something in continuous formation through choice of action.
author: John Dewey

text: If you care about what other people think, you will always be their prisoner.
author: James Frey

text: The two greatest warriors are patience and time.
author: Leo Tolstoy

text: Be careful when you fight the monsters, lest you become one.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

text: Nothing is more honourable than a grateful heart.
author: Seneca

text: A wise man gets more use from his enemies than a fool from his friends.
author: Baltasar Gracian

text: To understand is to be free.
author: Spinoza

text: From a seed a mighty trunk may grow.
author: Aeschylus

text: No one heals himself by wounding another.
author: Ambrose

text: The actions of men are the best interpreters of their thoughts.
author: John Locke

text: In order to succeed your desire for success should be greater than your fear of failure.
author: Anonymous

text: Each heart knows its own bitterness, and no one else can share its joy.
author: The Book of Proverbs

text: The mind unlearns with difficulty what it has long learned.
author: Seneca

text: Life is short, art long, opportunity is fleeting, experience is treacherous, and judgment is difficult.
author: Hypocrites

text: Hofstadter's Law: It always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter's Law.
author: Douglas Hofstadter

text: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.
author: Aristotle

text: All paid jobs absorb and degrade the mind.
author: Aristotle

text: The most painful state of being is remembering the future, particularly the one you'll never have.
author: Soren Kiekegaard

text: There is nothing permanent except change.
author: Heraclitus of Ephesus

text: We live but for a moment.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: It is possible to commit no mistakes and still lose. That is not a weakness; that is life.
author: Jean-Luc Picard

text: Only the educated are free.
author: Epictetus

text: If a man takes no thought what is distant, he will find sorrow near at hand.
author: Confucius

text: It doesn't matter how slowly you go as long as you don't stop.
author: Confucius

text: We shall never have more time. We have, and have always had, all the time there is.
author: Arnold Bennett
source: How to live on 24 hours a day

text: The man who dares to waste an hour of time has not discovered the value of his life.
author: Charles Darwin

text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: There is no more miserable human being than the one for whom the beginning of every bit of work must be decided anew each day.
author: William James

text: Know that no one is free, except Zeus.
author: Aeschylus

text: Hard work isn't enough, and more work is never the real answer.
author: Reid Hoff

text: If I am not for myself, who will be for me? But if I am only for myself, who am I? If not now, when?.
author: Hillel

text: Fall seven, rise eight.
author: Japanese saying

text: Self-control in a man who does not act wisely is the weakest of all things.
author: Aeschylus

text: Growth begins when we begin to accept our own weakness.
author: Jean Vanier

text: Last words are for people who haven't said anyting in life.
author: Karl Marx

text: Poverty of goods is easily cured; poverty of soul, impossible.
author: Michel de Montaigne

text: We do not judge the people we love.
author: Jean-Paul Sartre

text: A youth is to be regarded with respect. How do we know that his future will not be equal to our present?
author: Confucius

text: To be a hero or a heroine, one must give an order to oneself.
author: Simone Weil

text: Not life, but good life, is to be chiefly valued.
author: Socrates

text: Never listen to people who speak badly of others and good of you.
author: Tolstoy

text: Much that passes as idealism is disguised hatred or disguised love of power.
author: Bertrand Russell

text: If you put fences around people, you get sheep.
author: William L. McKnight

text: We make war that we may live in peace.
author: Aristotle

text: Mothers are fonder than fathers of their children because they are more certain they are their own.
author: Aristotle

text: Children have never been very good at listening to their elders, but they have never failed to imitate them.
author: James Baldin

text: Ignorance is the night of the mind, but a night without moon and star.
author: Confucius

text: Truth uttered before its time is always dangerous.
author: Mencius

text: What you are must always displease you, if you would attain to that which you are not.
author: Augustine

text: It is not titles that honour men, but men that honour titles.
author: Machiavelli

text: There is no such thing as the view from nowhere or from everywhere, for that matter. Our point of view biases our observation, consciously or unconsciously. You cannot understand the view without the point of view.
author: Noam Shpancer

text: A rabbit runs faster than a fox because it is running for his life while the fox is only running for his dinner. Richard Dawkins
He who begins being a friend for the sake of expediency will also stop for the sake of expediency.
author: Seneca

text: A wise man gets more use from his enemies than a fool from his friends.
author: Baltasar Gracian

text: War does not determine who is right, only who is left.
author: Bertrand Russell

text: He who speaks without modesty will find it difficult to make his words good.
author: Confucius

text: Inspiration is for amateurs.
author: Chuck Close

text: If your plan is for one year plant rice. If your plan is for ten years plant trees. If your plan is for one hundred years educate children.
author: Confucius

text: Love is the attempt to form a friendship inspired by beauty.
author: Cicero

text: All the tyrants of Sicily never invented a worse torment than envy.
author: Horace

text: All exact science is dominated by the idea of approximation.
author: Bertrand Russell

text: An error is the more dangerous the more truth it contains.
author: Henri Frederic Amiel

text: Government can exist without laws, but law cannot exist without government.
author: Bertrand Russell

text: I've never known any trouble that an hour's read didn't assuage.
author: Charles de Secondat

text: Instead of imagining that our main task is to instruct a computer what to do, let us concentrate rather on explaining to human beings what we want a computer to do.
author: Donald Knuth

text: Dost thou love life? Then do not squander time; for that's the stuff life is made of.
author: Benjamin Franklin

text: You are the easiest person to fool.
author: Richard Feynman

text: A little learning is a dangerous thing; drink deep, or taste not the Pierian spring: There shallow draughts intoxicate the brain, and drinking largely sobers us again.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A man who tosses worms in the river isn't necessarily a friend of the fish.
author: Malcom X

text: There is no conversation more boring than the one where everybody agrees.
author: Michel de Montaigne

text: If you find a path with no obstacles it probably doesn't lead anywhere.
author: Frank Clark

text: If you only read the books that everyone else is reading, you can only think what everyone else is thinking.  Haruki Murakami
A wealth of information creates a poverty of attention.
author: Herbert Simon

text: What is life, if full of care, we have not time to stop and stare.
author: W.H. Davies

text: Life is difficult.
author: M. Scott Peck

text: When brothers agree, no fortress is so strong as their common life.
author: Antisthenes

text: Cleverness is not wisdom.
author: Euripides

text: Kindly words do not enter so deeply into a men as a reputation for kindness.
author: Mencius

text: From a small seed a mighty trunk may grow.
author: Aeschylus

text: We know truth, not only reason, but also by the heart.
author: Blaise Pascal

text: Perserver and perserver yourselves for better circumstances.
author: Virgil

text: An object in possession seldom retains the same charm it had in pursuit.
author: Pliny the Younger

text: Having the fewest wants, I am nearest to the gods.
author: Socrates

text: Words are doctors to a diseased temperament.
author: Aeschylus

text: Everything new comes from some other beginning's end.
author: Seneca

text: Poverty is the parent of revolution and crime.
author: Aristotle

text: Know not to revere human things too much.
author: Aeschylus

text: The firm, the enduring, the simple and the modest are near to virtue.
author: Confucius

text: A man of understanding has lost nothing, if he has himself.
author: Michel de Montaigne

text: The fox has many tricks. The hedgehog has but one. But that is the best of all.
author: Desiderius Erasmus

text: You cannot truly listen to anyone and do anything else at the same time.
author: M. Scott Peck

text: There is no greater concurrence between learning and wisdom.
author: Sir Francis Bacon

text: Pleasure is the beginning and the end of living happily.
author: Epicurus

text: Do not ask for what you will wish you had not got.
author: Seneca

text: Even the king in his riches does not escape death.
author: Aeschylus

text: The most profound joy has more of gravity than of gaiety in it.
author: Michel de Montaigne

text: Blushing is the colour of virtue.
author: Diogenes Laertius

text: The higher you climb on the mountain, the harder the wind blows.
author: Sam Cummings

text: Freedom of opinion can only exist when the government thinks itself secure.
author: Bertrand Russell

text: Men never do evil so completely and cheerfully as when they do it from a religious conviction.
author: Blaise Pascal

text: If the only prayer you ever say in your whole life is 'thank you', that would suffice.
author: Meister Eckhart

text: The smile is the beginning of love.
author: Mother Teresa

text: Again, men in general desire the good, and not merely what their fathers had.
author: Aristotle

text: These are not the problems associated with the ministry, they are the ministry.
author: Bishop of Kensington

text: To find yourself, think for yourself.
author: Socrates

text: The measure of who we are is how we react to something that doesn't go our way.
author: Gregg Popovich

text: I care not so much what I am to others as what I am to myself.
author: Michel de Montaigne

text: The most necessary learning is that which unlearns evil.
author: Antisthenes

text: Come what may, all bad fortune is to be conquered by endurance.
author: Virgil

text: In health there is freedom. Health is the first of all liberties.
author: Henric Frederic Amiel

text: To forget one's purpose is the commonest form of stupidity.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

text: Evil when we are in its power is not felt as evil but as a necessity, or even a duty.
author: Simone Weil

text: But what is happiness except the simple harmony between a man and life he leads?
author: Albert Camus

text: Even in civilized mankind faint traces of monogamous instincts can be perceived.
author: Bertrand Russell

text: Reading maketh a full man, conference a ready man, and writing an exact man.
author: Sir Francis Bacon

text: Life is neither good or evil, but only a place for good or evil.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: He who controls others may be powerful, but he who has mastered himself is mightier still.
author: Lao-tzu

text: Before you embark on a journey of revenge, dig two graves.
author: Confucius

text: Men despise religion. They hate it and are afraid it may be true.
author: Blaise Pascal

text: First learn the meaning of what you say and then speak.
author: Epictetus

text: Learn to be happy with what you have while you pursue all that you want.
author: Jim Rohn

text: It is hard to fight against emotion, but harder still to fight against pleasure.
author: Heraclitus

text: I have taken all knowledge to be my province.
author: Sir Francis Bacon

text: Socialism is nothing but the capitalism for the lower classes.
author: Oswald Spengler

text: Thou shouldest eat to live, not live to eat.
author: Socrates

text: Thrift is of great revenue.
author: Cicero

text: How will you ever be polished if you are irritated by every rub?
author: Rumi

text: Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a harder battle.
author: Plato

text: Who is blind, dumb and deaf will live a peaceful life of a hundred years.
author: Siddha Nagarjuna

text: Originality is the one thing which unoriginal minds cannot feel the use of.
author: John Stuart Mill

text: As soon as there is life there is danger.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

text: Bad mind, bad heart.
author: Anacharsis

text: Strangers are simply friends who have not yet met.
author: William Butler Yeats

text: Speak your truth quietly and clearly.
author: Desiderata

text: Complexity is failed simplicity.
author: Edward de Bono

text: An expert is a person who has made all the mistakes that can be made in a very narrow field.
author: Niels Bhor

text: Anyone who lives within their means suffers from a lack of imagination.
author: Oscar Wilde

text: Whenever you find yourself on the side of the majority it is time and reflect.
author: Mark Twain

text: Ordinarily he was insane, but he had lucid moments when he was merely stupid.
author: Heinrich Heine

text: Reality is an illusion, albeit a very persistent one.
author: Albert Einstein

text: Be silent, or say something better than silence
author: Pythagoras

text: The reasonable man adapts himself to the world; the unreasonable one persists in trying to adapt the world to himself. Therefore all progress depends on the unreasonable man.
author: George Bernard Shaw

text: It is not a lack of love, but a lack of friendship that makes unhappy marriages.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

text: Action may not bring happiness, but there can be no happiness without action.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

text: Keep your eyes open before marriage, and half shut afterwards.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

text: The first principle is that you must not fool yourself, and you are the easiest person to fool.
author: Richard Feynman

text: Trust one who has tried.
author: Virgil

text: Man is not a rational animal he is a rationalizing animal.
author: Robert A. Heinlein

text: We are twice armed if we fight with faith.
author: Plato
